page.title: 11Changes in Heywood.2.
page.content: Groups of {Senior Citizens }were interviewed. Most are over 70 and have lived in Heywood all their lives. All left school when they were 12 and some were half-timers. All said that school then was far stricter and some said that they had had better teachers. They all started work, mainly in the { {Cotton Industry. }They spoke of long hours and low pay , and most mentioned the short holidays,-just one week for many.They talked of the unemployment of the 1930's and the decline of the {Cotton Industry. }They mentioned their houses, especially the ones they grew up in, and the fact that they all had a shared outside toilet.Some of the houses they lived in when first married were still standing. They also talked about the old {Tramcars }and how they tended to walk as often as possible because it was cheaper.
